properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong wind gusts of 70 to 80 km/h expected Sunday. A strengthening low pressure system is forecast to track across northeastern Ontario Sunday with winds strengthening throughout the day. The highest winds are expected to be ushered in with the passage of a cold front, where southwest winds gusting up to 80 km/h are forecast. This front will move through southwestern Ontario beginning Sunday morning and through the Toronto to Barrie corridor in the afternoon. Local power outages are possible. Strong winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind will slowly ease Sunday night into Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-15T03:43:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-14T11:44:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1119613539.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy is expected tonight and Sunday. Snow is forecast to being tonight, become heavy during the day on Sunday and taper to scattered flurries early Monday morning. At this time, forecast guidance suggests that snowfall totals of 10 to 15 cm are possible. This snow event is associated with a strengthening low pressure system that is forecast to track northeastward across northeastern Ontario on Sunday. Reduced visibility in heavy snow and snow covered roads could potentially lead to hazardous driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-15T03:02:37-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected. In Ulukhaktok, 2 to 4 cm of falling snow and strong winds, with gusts up to 70 km/h, will cause blizzard conditions to begin later this morning. Blizzard conditions are expected to end this evening when the wind weakens. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-15T03:45:10-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds gusting up to 100 km/h expected Sunday afternoon. A strengthening low pressure system is forecast to track across northeastern Ontario Sunday. This system will bring southerly winds gusting up to 70 km/h by early Sunday morning. Even stronger southwesterly winds gusting up to 100 km/h will be ushered in with the passage of a cold front Sunday afternoon. Wind warnings are likely to be issued as the event draws near. Power outages are possible. Strong winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind will slowly ease Sunday night into Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-15T03:04:51-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing precipitation accumulations of 2 millimetres are expected during the day on Sunday in these areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind expected. A strengthening low pressure system that is forecast to track northeastward across northeastern Ontario will bring heavy rain and gusty winds to the region beginning tonight. Rainfall totals of 30 to 50 mm are possible by the time the rain changes to snow Sunday night. Strong south to southeasterly winds gusting to 70 km/h are also possible tonight. These winds should diminish for a few hours during the day on Sunday before shifting to very strong northwesterlies gusting up to 90 km/h late Sunday afternoon. Wind warnings may be issued as the event draws near. Strong wind gusts may toss lose objects or cause tree branches to break. Power outages may occur. The potential for strong wind gusts should end Monday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-15T03:08:04-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected beginning Sunday night. Total snowfall: 10 cm or more. Locations: Northwestern New Brunswick. Time span: Sunday night through Monday morning. Remarks: A low pressure system will approach from the west on Sunday. Snow will develop ahead of the low Sunday night and persist into Monday morning. The snow will be wet and mixed at times with rain, freezing rain or ice pellets. Current indications suggest that total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-15T00:54:11-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Colorado low will intensify over New England and affect Eastern Quebec Sunday and Monday. This storm will bring snow at times heavy, strong to high winds and even rain. Snowfall amounts could exceed 15 centimetres over several areas. Over the tip of the Gaspé Peninsula and Anticosti Island, precipitation will mainly fall as rain. We could see between 20 and 40 millimetres. Southeasterly winds could gust from 70 to 90 kilometres per hour over the tip of the Gaspé Peninsula and the Lower North Shore on Monday. The strong winds combined with the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal ranges may produce breaking sea conditions at Gaspé-Percé, on Anticosti Island and on the Lower North Shore Monday afternoon. Given the complexity of this system, it is still too early to determine the expected amounts of precipitation and the regions that will be the most affected. More information on this system's development will be provided as it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-15T01:43:21-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snow will persist over the Coquihalla Highway from Hope to Merritt tonight as a Pacific storm continues moving across the BC interior. Approximately 35 cm of snow has fallen since last night. Additional snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm can be expected by Saturday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-14T19:48:32-00:00

Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected over some areas. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: mainly inland sections of eastern Newfoundland. Time span: This afternoon until Sunday morning. Remarks: The highest snowfall amounts can be expected inland and over higher terrain. Most coastal areas should see much lower snowfall amounts as the snow occasionally mixes with or changes to rain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
